juiceboxgallery.galleryTitle: The Caltech Archives Present: There's something about Harry!

image.title: The Many sides of Harry - Scientist
image.caption: With Nobel Prize winner Linus Pauling, 1978. (Photographer unknown)

image.title: The Many sides of Harry - Commencement Speaker (& “Philosopher”!)
image.caption: Commencement, June 13, 1975. (Photo credi F. Clark)

image.title: The Many sides of Harry - Commencement Speaker (& “Philosopher”!)
image.caption: June 13, 1975, giving his Commencement Address entitled “The Chemistry Of Caltech”. Reprinted in the Oct/Nov 1975 E&S issue: http://tinyurl.com/odo4a59 (Photo credit F. Clark)

image.title: The Many sides of Harry - Commencement Speaker (& “Philosopher”!)
image.caption: Part of Dr. Gray’s “FEG Formula”—his three-part prescription for graduating seniors. “F” for Feynman: “Have absolute scientific integrity.” “E” for Einstein: “Do Science but with concern for mankind.” “G” for Gray: “If you don’t love it, don’t do it.” (Photo credit F. Clark)

image.title: The Many sides of Harry - Theatrical Star
image.caption: As “Harry the Horse” the crapshooter in Caltech’s musical production of Guys and Dolls, February 1977. (Photographer unknown)

image.title: The Many sides of Harry - Theatrical Star
image.caption: (Photographer unknown)

image.title: The Many sides of Harry - Respected and Honored Professional
image.caption: Arnold Beckman congratulating Harry Gray on becoming the first Arnold O. Beckman Professor of Chemistry, 1981. (Photographer unknown)

image.title: The Many sides of Harry - Respected and Honored Professional
image.caption: Harry Gray receiving the 1986 National Medal of Science from President Ronald Reagan at the White House. (Photographer unknown)

image.title: The Many sides of Harry - Respected and Honored Professional
image.caption: The Founding Director of the Beckman Institute, October 1989. (Photographer unknown)

image.title: The Many sides of Harry - Respected and Honored Professional
image.caption: Harry Gray, together with William P. Schaefer, designed the sculpture “The Polyhedron with 432 Symmetry,” located in the Glanville Courtyard of the Beckman Institute, October 1989. In 1992, the City of Pasadena deemed it to be one of the ten best examples of public art. (Photographer unknown)

image.title: The Many sides of Harry - Respected and Honored Professional
image.caption: Dr. Gray wearing Columbia University’s commencement gown, with the white-striped symbol of an honorary degree from France’s University of Paul Sabatier, on the occasion of receiving an honorary doctorate from Columbia, where he taught from 1961 to 1966. May 27, 1994.. (Photographer unknown)

image.title: The Many sides of Harry - Harry just being Harry!
image.caption: Celebrating his 60th birthday in 1995. (Photographer unknown)

image.title: The Many sides of Harry - Harry just being Harry!
image.caption: (Photographer unknown)
